title-group.article-title: Horizontal axis wind turbine dynamic stall predictions based on wind speed and direction variability

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Amanullah Choudhry, Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, SA 5005, Adelaide, Australia. Email: amanullah.choudhry@adelaide.edu.au

abstract.p: The onset of dynamic stall in horizontal axis wind turbines (HAWTs) is related to the rapid increase in the angle of attack caused by sudden changes in wind speed and direction. In order to relate the changes in wind speed and direction with the variations in the blade-section angle of attack, an analytical model is proposed to determine the regions of the blade affected by dynamic stall. The so-called threshold radius has been identified and defined as the percentage of the blade length from the horizontal axis wind turbines hub beyond which the probability of dynamic stall occurrence falls to zero. High quality wind data were acquired to determine the average wind conditions that serve as the model inputs. It is shown that the rate of change of wind speed, due to gusts or the average turbulence, can cause large regions of dynamic stall on the wind turbine blade. Other parameters, such as the yaw misalignment and the rate of change of yaw angle are shown to be the cause of asymmetrical distribution of threshold radius with azimuth and also serve to increase the affected regions. Finally it is shown that the type of airfoil used in the turbine blade also has a significant effect on the threshold radius due to the different limiting reduced frequencies.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Wind is the fastest growing renewable energy source in the world1 and wind turbines have been commercially used for over four decades for electricity production. Over this period the size and the energy yield of the wind turbine have increased dramatically.2 However, despite the rapid advancements in the design and manufacturing, wind turbines still need to operate in harsh and unpredictable environments. Due to the stochastic nature of wind, wind turbines are susceptible to large and temporally varying unsteady loads, which consequently result in fatigue damage of the turbine blades, causing higher maintenance costs or reduction of the turbine life.

One of the major causes of unsteady loads on the turbine is the occurrence of dynamic stall on the turbine blades. Dynamic stall is considered to be the delay of stall that results in a drastic increase in lift experienced by an airfoil as the static stall angle is suddenly exceeded.3 It is also characterised by the formation of a large leading-edge vortex during the later stages of the pitching cycle. As soon as the vortex convects over the airfoil and sheds, the airfoil goes into a state of deep stall. After this the flow is completely separated and reattaches only when the angle of attack is brought down to a sufficiently low value. The process has been well documented and readers are referred to Carr et al.4 for further details.

Dynamic stall in wind turbines can be caused by unsteady inflow, yaw misalignment, tower shadow and rapid increases in wind speeds or gusts, all of which contribute to the rapid variations in the blade angle of attack. The effects of tower shadow and yaw misalignment have been studied in detail by wind tunnel experiments.5 In fact, according to a conservative estimate, it was found that for a yawed horizontal axis wind turbine (HAWT), dynamic stall was observed to occur for more than 50% of the recorded cycles.6 Furthermore, it has been suggested that gusts can also lead to a state of dynamic stall.7 Since the wind turbine blades experience a large increase in lift, the gust loads on the turbine blade are more severe than the stalled loads.8 Prior to the dynamic stall vortex convection, these large loads and bending moments are even capable of breaking the blade.9 The deep stall experienced as the primary dynamic stall vortex is shed, and the subsequent process of vortex shedding, can lead to the vibration of the blade, adversely affecting the life of the turbine.

The effects of dynamic stall on the wind turbine blades are significant; however, at present no information exists which relates the actual wind conditions (i.e. rapidly changing wind speeds and directions) to the dynamic alterations in the blade angle of attack. Such information will be useful to predict the regions of the wind turbine blades that are under the influence of dynamic stall. To this end, in the current article, a theoretical method has been proposed that uses the ambient wind conditions as inputs to determine the distribution of reduced frequency along the blade length at different azimuth angles. Using this distribution the predictions of dynamic stall occurrence along a wind turbine blade have been achieved and presented. The method outlined in the article provides a toolbox for determination of the regions of a wind turbine blade where dynamic stall control is required.

sec.title: Analytical model for rate of change of angle of attack
sec.p:
In this section, an analytical model has been derived that can be used to determine the rate of change of angle of attack along the turbine blade, based on ambient wind conditions. Using this analytical model, the regions of the wind turbine blade where dynamic stall occurrence is expected can be determined. For the purpose of the derivation, the geometric relationship between the inflow variables and the angles involved for a wind turbine blade are illustrated in Figure 1.10 Figure 1(a) and (b) illustrates the front and the top view of the wind turbine respectively whereas Figure 1(c) shows a cross-section of the turbine blade. From Figure 1(b), it can be observed that the incoming wind speed can be resolved into components that are normal to and across the plane of disc rotation. Therefore, the normal (Vn) and the cross-flow (Vn) velocity components are given by (1)Vn=VWcosγ (2)Vc=-VWsinγ Figure 1.
A schematic illustration of a wind turbine indicating the geometric relationship between the inflow variables and the angles involved.

Note that in equations (1) and (2), the effects of induced velocities due to the rotor disc have been ignored for simplicity. The rotor disc induces a velocity variation caused by the expansion of the stream-tube of air approaching the rotor. The corrections are applied to the free-stream velocity by including the axial induction factors or the inflow factors. However, the induced velocity corrections have been ignored for simplicity.

The cross-flow velocity vector can be resolved into the tangential (Vt) and the spanwise (Vs) components. The tangential component is directly related to the rotor rotational speed and is one of the primary variables affecting the rotor dynamics. On the other hand, the span-wise component is dependent on the yaw angle and is usually very small even for moderate yaw angles. From Figure 1, the tangential (Vt) and the spanwise (Vs) components of velocity are given by (3)Vt=rω+Vccosψ=rω-VWsinγcosψ (4)Vs=-VWsinγsinψ
Therefore the resultant velocity (Vtot) experienced by the blade section, as shown in Figure 1(c), is the vector sum of all components of velocity (5)Vtot=Vn2+Vt2+Vs2
In order to determine the rate of change of angle of attack (α·), let us define an angle ϕ such that from Figure 1(c) α+β=ϕ=tan-1VnVt
Differentiating the above equation with respect to time gives (sec2ϕ)d(ϕ)dt=VtV·n-VnV·tVt2d(ϕ)dt=(cos2ϕ)[VtV·n-VnV·tVt2]
On the other hand, note that since α+β=ϕ, therefore α·+β·=ϕ·

In the above equations, β is the pitch angle of the turbine blade and is generally varied for optimum performance of a wind turbine. The blade pitch angle also serves the purpose to mediate the rotor speed within the operating limits as the wind speed increases. Most large-scale modern horizontal axis wind turbines have an active pitch control mechanism. However, due to the large inertia of the blade, the time rate of change of pitch angle is kept very small. On the other hand, for small-scale wind turbines that are generally stall-regulated (without an active pitch control mechanism), the rate of change of pitch angle is zero. Therefore, for all classes of wind turbines, the rate of change of pitch angle can be ignored in comparison to the rate of change of angle of attack. Hence (6)ϕ·=α·=(cos2ϕ)[VtV·n-VnV·tVt2]

Therefore, from equation (6), it can be observed that in order to calculate the rate of change of angle of attack on the wind turbine blade, the normal and tangential components of the resultant velocity are required along with the derivatives of these parameters. To calculate V·n, let us differentiate equation (1) with respect to time (7)V·n=V·Wcosγ-VWsinγ(γ·)

From equation (7), the time derivative of the normal component of resultant velocity depends on the mean wind speed, mean yaw angle, the rate of change of wind speed and the rate of change of yaw angle. The standard deviation in wind speed can be taken as the measure of the average rate of change of wind speed, as proposed by Melbourne.11 In a similar manner, the average rate of change of yaw angle is given by the standard deviation of the yaw angle. Therefore V·W=(ν'2persec)γ·=(rms(γ)persec)

Using the standard deviation as the measure of the rate of change of wind speed yields the average wind fluctuations that will be observed over the averaging time. In order to consider the effects of the peak gust on the wind turbine, the rate of change of wind speed can be given as V·W=Vgmax(h)-VW(h)(tg/2)

In the previous equation, Vgmax(h) is the peak gust at height h and tg is the gust duration. It is important to note that the gust duration is an important parameter since it directly affects the rate of change of wind speed. Gust duration is a measure of the duration of the peak gust and is dependent on the frequency response of the measuring instrument. Therefore, slow-response systems indicate long smooth gusts, whereas fast-response systems, such as the ones used for the present study, indicate sharp gusts of short durations. However, short-duration-gusts have neither the time nor the horizontal extent to exert their full effects on large structures. Therefore, the proper scale of gust duration as suggested by the WMO12 is between 3 and 4 s. It can therefore be argued that very high time response system is not needed for the current study. For the purpose of the present research, gust duration of 4 s is used.
Differentiating equation (3) with respect to time gives the time-derivative of the tangential component of resultant velocity (V·t) V·t=(r·ω+rω·)-[V·Wsinγcosψ+VWcosγcosψ(γ·) +VWsinγ(-sinψ)(ψ·)]

Note that in this equation, the parameter r· has no physical meaning and is equal to zero. Let us assume that the wind turbine has a fixed-speed rotor and therefore the rate of change of rotational speed will be zero (ω·=0). However, for a variable-speed rotor, ω· will have a certain value and should be included in the calculations. Note that the rate at which the azimuth angle varies with time is simply equal to the rotor rotational speed (ψ·=ω). Hence the equation simplifies to (8)V·t=-[V·Wsinγcosψ+VWcosγcosψ(γ·) -VWsinγsinψ(ω)]

For a particular set of averaged wind conditions, inserting equations (1), (2), (7) and (8) into equation (6) gives the average rate of change of angle of attack. Instantaneous rates can also be achieved using the same equations. Note that equation (6) gives the rate of change of angle of attack as a function of the wind speed, yaw angle, azimuth angle and the time rates of change of these parameters.

The dynamic stall process is a complex function of the freestream velocity, the pitching rate and the airfoil geometric properties.13 The reduced frequency is considered to be the most important parameter affecting dynamic stall on an airfoil since it incorporates the pitch rate, the airfoil chord length and the freestream velocity into a single parameter. Therefore, the reduced frequency can be considered as the non-dimensional measure of the rate of change of angle of attack for wind turbines and is given by (9)k=πα·cVtot

In equation (9), α· is the rate of change of angle of attack experienced at the section due to unsteady motion of the blade section (airfoil) or due to unsteady conditions experienced at the blade section, given by equation (6), c is the chord length of the blade section, and Vtot is the average resultant velocity experienced at the section, given by equation (5).

Note that for a wind turbine, the phenomenon is even more complicated since the angle of attack is directly related to the freestream velocity. Therefore, due to a gust event, the blade angle of attack might increase at a large rate. However, due to the simultaneous increase in the wind speed, the reduced frequency might be small.

Using the above method, the distribution of reduced frequency, based on the ambient wind conditions, can be calculated for a given wind turbine blade. As noted from earlier experiments,14 the inboard regions of the wind turbine blade are highly susceptible to the ambient wind conditions, due to the smaller tangential velocities as compared to the outboard regions of the blade. This leads to larger variations in the blade angle of attack at these sections when exposed to gusts, yaw and high rates of change of wind direction. In terms of the model, this implies that the reduced frequency and consequently the rate of change of angle of attack are larger at the root regions and decrease along the blade length as we move towards the tip of the blade. Therefore, based on the ambient wind conditions and the type of airfoil, the frequency and probability of dynamic stall occurrence will decrease from the root towards the tip of the blade. The percentage of the blade length beyond which the probability of dynamic stall occurrence on the blade falls to zero (for any given ambient wind conditions) is termed, in the present article, the ‘threshold radius’. The threshold radius is, therefore, a parameter of significant importance and needs to be determined in order to calculate the load distribution on the wind turbine blade due to dynamic stall. Another application of threshold radius is the determination of the position of control devices along the blade span to suppress the effects of dynamic stall.

It is important to note that the type of airfoil will also have a significant effect on the occurrence of dynamic stall on the wind turbine blade. As defined by Leishman,15 dynamic stall occurs on airfoils when the critical angle of attack (the stall angle) is exceeded at a significant pitch rate. However, a considerable amount of research still needs to be conducted in order to determine the limiting reduced frequency for an airfoil (the non-dimensional pitch rate below which dynamic stall is not observed on the airfoil) and the parameters on which it depends upon, such as airfoil shape and Reynolds number. For example, according to McCroskey et al.,16 dynamic stall experiments on a NACA 0012 airfoil yielded slight hysteresis in the forces and boundary layer separation and reattachment for reduced frequency values as low as 0.004. However, it was not until a reduced frequency of 0.05 was tested that the salient features of dynamic stall became apparent, marking the onset of the phenomena for the NACA 0012 airfoil. Similarly, for an S809 airfoil, it was observed that significant hysteresis in the force coefficient characteristics occur for a Reynolds number of 1 × 106 when the reduced frequency is 0.026,17 even though this is not mentioned in the article itself. However, beyond these two examples, there is not much systematic work that has been done in order to determine the limiting reduced frequency of different airfoils and the effects of airfoil geometric parameters and the Reynolds number on the limiting reduced frequency. Such a study offers the distinct advantage in the design and proper choice of airfoil for wind turbine blades that inherently resist dynamic stall. For example, for the same wind conditions, the NACA 0012 airfoil will resist dynamic stall to a larger degree than the S809 airfoil, as evident from the figures of limiting reduced frequencies provided earlier.

sec.title: Limitations of the model
sec.p:
It is worth stating here that several simplifying assumptions have been made during the derivation. These are highlighted as follows.
The model is applicable to fixed-speed rotors. This is not a limitation, since application to variable-speed rotors simply requires the inclusion of ω· term in the equation (8). The term was ignored here for simplicity.
The expansion of the stream tube as the flow approaches the rotor plane, which results in reduction of velocities, has not been included in the model. The effects can be catered by the inclusion of axial induction factors and the corrections are applied to the freestream velocity. However, at this stage the parameter has been ignored for simplicity.
The induced velocity field depends on the distribution of vorticity in the entire wake and the effects become more prominent when the wake is not symmetrical, such as operation under yawed flow.18 The effects a of skewed wake were first noted by Coleman et al.19 for helicopters and were introduced as a model. These authors also observed that induced velocities were reduced at the upwind edge of the rotor and increased at the downwind end of the rotor. The model was adapted for wind turbines by Swift Jr20 and later used by Hansen18 for his YawDyn program. The skewed-wake-induced velocity correction is a simple linear adjustment applied upon a constant induced velocity across the rotor disc that permits the physical effects to be modelled without going into the details of higher order corrections. However, since the axial inductions were ignored for simplicity, the correction necessary due to the skewed wake was not considered at this stage.
The effects of the tower on the flow have been ignored in the model. For the upwind rotor, the presence of the tower results in the redirection of the flow directly in front of the tower. The slight adjustment required for the wind speed can be catered for by the model proposed by Dolan and Lehn.21 The effects of the tower on an upwind rotor are relatively small; however, when compared with the effects on a downwind rotor. In the latter case, blades passing the wake of the tower experience the vortices being shed by the tower and reduced velocities. The tower shadow velocity deficit model, proposed by Hansen,18 can be used to include these effects. The model is a simple cosine function and is dependent on the azimuth angle, but does not include the phenomenon of vortex shedding and always centres the wake at an azimuth of zero degrees regardless of the yaw angle. In order to include the effects of yaw on the tower shadow, the model proposed by Wang and Coton,22 can be used to precisely determine the regions of the blade that will be influenced by the tower shadow. For simplicity, the model developed in the current article does not cater for the changes in the flow field due to the presence of the tower.
It is worth stating that, based on the ambient wind conditions, the model might predict that the entire wind turbine blade is influenced by dynamic stall. However, near the tip of a wind turbine blade, the flow field will be affected by radial flows along the trailing edge as well as the tip-vortex generation. Therefore, predictions in these regions might not be accurate.
It is important to note that in the current model, the effects of Reynolds number variation along the turbine blade have been ignored primarily due to the lack of information as highlighted in the previous section. It is anticipated that as the Reynolds number increases, the limiting reduced frequency of the airfoil should also increase, thus delaying the onset of dynamic stall phenomenon to more severe conditions. However, incorporating the effects of Reynolds number in the current model requires further experimental work.

The induced velocities, skewed wakes and the tower wake lead to an increase in the rate of change of angle of attack that will be experienced by the rotor blade section. This will therefore result in an increase of the affected regions on the blades. On the other hand, including the effects of Reynolds number variation along the blade span will result in the decrease of the overall affected regions. Therefore, the measurements given in the present article can be considered to be conservative estimates. In the future, the above-mentioned effects will be incorporated into the model for more realistic analysis of a general wind turbine.

sec.title: Validation of the model
sec.p: The NREL Phase VI HAWT was used for the purpose of validation of the analytical model. The specific HAWT used for the purpose of validation of the model is the one described by Schreck et al.,14 which was tested in the NASA Ames 24.4 m × 36.6 m wind tunnel. The NREL HAWT has a diameter of 10.1 m with a taper ratio of 0.483. The taper distribution is quite important to consider since the reduced frequency is dependent on the chord length. In this case the wind turbine blade is based on the S809 airfoil for which the limiting reduced frequency is 0.026. The specific case study considered here is when the turbine is rotating at an r/min of 71.6, the mean wind speed is 13 m/s and the yaw angle is 40°. Note that there are no variations in wind speed or direction in this case. Therefore the rate of change of wind speed and direction are zero.

The percentage of the blade span under dynamic stall (i.e. the threshold radius) was calculated using the analytical model based on the wind conditions in the tunnel at selected azimuth angles. The distribution of the reduced frequency at a particular azimuth angle was compared with the limiting reduced frequency of the S809 airfoil (0.026). The regions of the turbine blade where the calculated reduced frequency was larger than the limiting reduced frequency are the dynamic-stall-affected regions. The boundary between these affected and non-affected regions is shown using a linear variation of threshold radius between the selected azimuth angles. The distribution of threshold radius with azimuth angle for the NREL HAWT is shown in Figure 2(a). For comparison, the variation of the normal force coefficient with the azimuth angle for the same turbine is presented in Figure 2(b) for two span-wise stations (0.30 R and 0.63 R). Note that the term ‘span-wise station’ corresponds to the sectional plane at a given radius. These plots have been reproduced from Schreck et al.14 and are illustrated here for comparison. It is important to note that the normal force coefficients plots presented here were obtained using the pressure distribution at the corresponding span-wise station. Slight variations were observed by the authors of the original experiment and the results reported were averaged over the duration of the experiment. Figure 2.
Validation of the analytical model using the NREL Phase VI HAWT: (a) threshold radius distribution with azimuth angle for the NREL Phase VI wind turbine, operating at an r/min of 71.6, at mean wind speed of 13 m/s and a yaw angle of 40°; (b) plots of normal force coefficient vs. the azimuth angle for two sections along the turbine blade (0.30 R and 0.63 R).14
HAWT: horizontal axis wind turbine.

It is well-known that an increase in the angle of attack results in the increase of the normal force coefficient, for the static as well as the dynamic case. Therefore, the angle of attack histories at each span-wise station can be deciphered from the plots of the normal force coefficient with azimuth angle. This is because an increase in the normal force coefficient results from the increase in the angle of attack. Therefore dCndψ∝dαdψ

Hence, the particular angle of attack histories with respect to the azimuth angle can be interpreted from Figure 2(b). It is also worth noting that for the S809, the maximum normal force coefficient is approximately 0.94 (Reynolds number of the order of 106).23 Therefore, as the normal force coefficients exceed the steady-state maximum value at a span-wise station, it can be deduced that the corresponding station is under the influence of dynamic stall.

The analytical model predicts that, based on the wind conditions experienced by the wind turbine, the blade will not be affected by dynamic stall at and near an azimuth of 0°, as can be observed from Figure 2(a). Comparing with the plots in Figure 2(b), it can be observed that the normal force coefficients level off as the 0° azimuth angle is approached. This indicates that the blade angle of attack is no longer changing and the rate of change of angle of attack, and hence the reduced frequency, is zero. Therefore, the blade will not experience dynamic stall at an azimuth angle of 0°.

Moreover, it can be observed from Figure 2(a) that the analytical model predicts that during the first half of the rotation cycle (0° < ψ < 180°), the threshold radius is zero and therefore, the blade is primarily free from dynamic stall. Comparing this with Figure 2(b), it can be observed that the normal force coefficients are decreasing for both span-wise stations during the first half of the rotation cycle. This indicates a decrease in the angle of attack at both stations during the first half of the rotation cycle and results in a negative reduced frequency (pitch-down motion) in this region. However, for the validation, negative pitching is not considered to be the cause of dynamic stall. On the other hand, for the case studies, presented later, negative pitching is also considered to cause dynamic stall.

Furthermore, as seen in Figure 2(a), the regions close to an azimuth angle of 180° also show dynamic-stall-free regions according to the model. However, in the original experiment, large variations in the angles of attack were observed near the azimuth angle of 180° due to the presence of the tower. Note that the tower shadow is not centred at an azimuth of 180° due to yawed-operation and the effects become apparent at a slightly earlier azimuth angle. This can be observed from Figure 2(b), where the normal force coefficients start to increase just before the azimuth of 180°, indicating an increase in the angle of attack. However, this behaviour is not captured by the analytical model, since the effects of the tower shadow were ignored.

From Figure 2(a), it can be observed that based on the analytical model, between 70% and 75% of the blade length is under dynamic stall during the second half of the rotation cycle (180° < ψ < 360°). Compare this with Figure 2(b), where the considerable rate of increase in the normal force coefficients indicates large excursions in the angles of attack at the two span-wise stations during the second half of the rotation cycle. In addition, the high values of the normal force coefficients also indicate that dynamic stall has indeed occurred during this range of azimuth angles. The dynamic-stall-affected regions of the NREL wind turbine obtained using the analytical model correspond to those observed by Schreck et al.,14 who concluded that, under the said wind conditions, dynamic stall is observed at approximately two thirds of the aerodynamically active blade, during the second half of the rotation cycle. Considering that the aerodynamically active part of the blade begins at 0.25 R, this corresponds to 0.755 R from the rotor hub. Hence, it can be seen that even with the simplifications assumed in the derivation of the model, the model is sufficiently accurate in capturing the regions of the turbine blade affected by dynamic stall.

sec.title: Model inputs
sec.p: As mentioned earlier, the ambient wind conditions such as the mean wind speed, mean yaw angle and the rate of change of these parameters, serve as the inputs for the model. In this section, the processing of wind data has been presented for use in the model. For the model, the average wind conditions at each height can be used to determine the average threshold radius. The wind data presented here were originally recorded at the Surface Layer Turbulence and Environmental Science Test (SLTEST) facility in the western salt flats of Utah.24,25 In the original experiments, the measurement domain consisted of a spanwise and wall-normal array of 3D sonic anemometers (Campbell Scientific CSAT3) in an ‘L’ shaped formation. The anemometers measured the three components of the velocity at a sampling rate of 20 Hz, where all measurements were conducted simultaneously. Further details of the original experiment can be found in Hutchins et al.25

For the purpose of the current research, since the wind conditions at the turbine rotor plane were required, only the measurements taken at the wall-normal array were used. The wall-normal array consisted of nine sonic anemometers arranged in the vertical direction from a height of 1.42–25.69 m. The data used in the current work are for 1 h during neutral atmospheric conditions. Neutral conditions simply imply that the adiabatic cooling of the air as it rises is such that the air parcel remains in thermal equilibrium with its surroundings.8

The resultant velocity and the yaw angle as seen by a wind turbine blade, the rotational axis of which is permanently aligned with the principal measurement axis of the sonic anemometers, are shown in Figure 3 and Figure 4 for an interval of 60 s and two heights namely 3.00 m and 17.94 m. The presentation of two heights only is done to aid clarity. Figure 3.
Resultant wind speed experienced by the turbine blade at selected heights.
Figure 4.
Instantaneous yaw angle experienced by the wind turbine. It is assumed that the rotor axis of the wind turbine is permanently aligned with the principal measurement axis of the anemometers.

It can be observed from both Figure 3 and Figure 4 that as the height increases, the level of turbulence in the atmosphere decreases. This can be observed by comparing the fluctuations in velocity and the yaw angle for both heights. Furthermore, as the height is increased, the mean wind speed increases. However, it is interesting to note that the mean yaw angle is not significantly affected by height.

However, in most cases, the variation of wind parameters with height or high frequency data as shown in Figure 3 and Figure 4 may not be readily available for general engineering purposes. Therefore, empirical approximations are more commonly employed to determine the variation of mean wind conditions with height. In the following, empirical approximations for mean wind speeds, turbulence intensities and peak-gusts are presented and compared with the SLTEST data.

Generally, in wind engineering, an averaging interval of 10 min or 1 h is used. In the following (Figure 5), an averaging interval of 1 h is used to show the variation of mean wind conditions with height for the SLTEST data. It can be observed from Figure 5 that the mean wind speeds increase with height as expected in the atmospheric surface layer. Furthermore, it can be observed from Figure 5, that the standard deviation in mean wind speed (indicated by error bars) also decreases with height. The mean wind speed is fitted using the power law with the Hellman’s exponent of 0.1, as suggested by26–28 (10)VW(h)VW(hr)=[hhr]e Figure 5.
Wind speed and turbulence intensity averaged over 1 h, along with the peak gust observed during this time. The empirically determined mean wind speed, turbulence intensity and the peak gust from the SLTEST data are also shown in the plot.
SLTEST: surface layer turbulence and environmental science test.

In the above equation, VW(h) is the average wind speed at height h, VW(hr) is the average wind speed at reference height hr (8.71 m) and e is Hellman’s exponent. The Hellman’s exponent depends on the roughness of the local terrain, atmospheric stability and the time over which the wind speed is averaged.26 Therefore, as seen in Figure 5, the averaged wind speeds are modelled quite accurately using the power law and is in accordance with the standards.

The variation of peak gust with height is also important when considering dynamic stall on wind turbines due to the fact that gusts play the most important role in dynamic alterations of blade angle of attack. In Figure 5, the variation of the peak gust observed over the hour of wind data is plotted as a function of height. In order to empirically determine the variation of the peak gust with height, the power law was used again. However in this case, as prescribed by Deacon,29 a smaller power should be used due to the slower increase of peak gust with height as compared to the mean wind speed. Therefore, the Hellman’s exponent of 0.045 was found to give the best fit.

The time-averaged stream-wise turbulence intensities at various heights are also illustrated in Figure 5 along with the empirically determined turbulence intensities. The averaging time in this case is 1 h as well. It can be observed that due to the increase in the wind speed, the turbulence intensity with height decreases, as expected in the atmospheric surface layer. For the neutral surface layer, as proposed by Panofsky,30 the stream-wise turbulence intensity (Ix) is given as a function of the surface roughness (ho) and height (h) as follows (11)Ix=0.88ln(h/ho)

According to ESDU,26 the surface roughness length corresponding to the Hellman’s exponent of 0.1 is 10−4 m. Using this surface roughness length, it can be observed from Figure 5 that the empirically determined turbulence intensities using Panofsky30 quite accurately represent the behaviour of averaged turbulence intensities with height. It is worth noting that the turbulence intensity predictions using the above formula is according to the Danish standards31 for safety of wind turbine construction.

The variation of average wind direction with height, as seen by the sonic anemometers, is shown in Figure 6 along with the standard deviation (enclosed rectangles). The minimum and maximum wind angles observed are also shown. It can be seen from the plot that the average wind direction does not vary considerably with height and that there is no specific trend in the variation of average wind direction with height. The average wind direction as seen by the anemometers is between –9° to –12° relative to the probe axes. This is in accordance with the results of Harris,32 who showed that over open country terrain, there is little change in average wind direction with height. The slight variation observed in Figure 6 could be explained by the possible presence of a small misalignment between the probes. The rectangles surrounding the mean wind direction in the plot represent one standard deviation on either side of the mean. It can be observed that the standard deviation decreases only slightly with height, indicating a decrease in turbulence intensity, such that it is a little over 4° at a height of 3.00 m and decreases to about 3.5° at a height of 17.94 m. Note that the average wind directions and the standard deviations observed at each height are approximately in the centre of the minimum and maximum wind angles observed. Therefore, it can be inferred quite easily that most of the wind direction data primarily lie in the rectangular regions. It is important to note that a general statement regarding the variation of wind direction with height and its relationship with turbulence intensity is not possible at this stage due to the small data interval of 1 h. A much larger data set, possibly of months in duration, would be required to derive any suitable relationships. Figure 6.
Time-averaged wind direction as seen by the sonic anemometers at various heights. The standard deviation (measure of rate of change of wind direction) is also presented as the rectangles surrounding the average wind directions at each height. Finally, the boundaries specify the maximum and minimum wind angles observed at each height.

The purpose of presenting the variation of different wind parameters with height and the empirical expressions used to achieve these relations is to illustrate that the method presented in the article can be applied readily without the need of high quality wind data at different heights. For most engineering applications, the empirical relations presented in this article can serve the purpose satisfactorily.

sec.title: Case studies
sec.p: As defined earlier, the threshold radius is the percentage of the blade length beyond which the probability of dynamic stall occurrence falls to zero, based on ambient wind conditions. The threshold radius can be determined by first computing the distribution of reduced frequency along the blade length at a particular azimuth angle. At the selected azimuth, the reduced frequency distribution along the blade length can then be compared with the limiting reduced frequency of the airfoil from 2D experiments. Therefore, the regions where the computed reduced frequency is larger than the limiting reduced frequency for the airfoil are deemed to be the dynamic-stall-affected-regions of the turbine blade. Repeating the process for selected azimuth angles then gives the distribution of threshold radius over the complete cycle of rotation, based on the ambient wind conditions. Therefore, in the following, the threshold radius distribution is represented as a contour line connecting the absolute limiting reduced frequency over the selected azimuth angles. Note that we have used the term ‘absolute’ in the previous statement. This is due to the fact that the airfoil, especially a symmetric airfoil, will experience dynamic stall during pitched down motions and therefore ‘negative gusts’ will also result in dynamic stall.

In this section, the effects of wind speed, yaw angle and the rates of change of wind speed and yaw angle are illustrated through two case studies by using the analytical model developed in the article. The two case studies are performed using a theoretical wind turbine with a rotor diameter of 15 m and a tower height of 10 m. A constant chord length of 3 m is used along the blade length and the blade is rotating at 30 r/min. The hourly averaged wind conditions, presented earlier in Figure 5 and Figure 6, are used to obtain the average threshold radius distribution for selected azimuth angles. As stated earlier, the empirical relations can also be used for this purpose. In order to illustrate the effects of a small yaw misalignment, the data was not corrected for direction and it is assumed that the rotor plane is aligned with the measurement axis of the sonic anemometers. Therefore, the yaw angle is simply taken to be constant with height, as shown in Figure 6, as −11°. Similarly, the average standard deviation with height is taken to be the rate of change of yaw angle (4°/s). Note that, in general, a wind turbine will have an active or passive yaw control mechanism to adjust for the changing wind direction. For such a case, the mean yaw angle will generally be zero and the yaw rate of the turbine will have an effect on the rate of change of yaw angle due to rapidly changing wind directions. However, here, for the purpose of demonstration, it is assumed that the turbine rotational axis is permanently aligned with the principal measurement axis of the anemometers.

Two cases are being presented here based on the rate of change of wind speed. The first is the average threshold radius that will be observed during the hour. For this case, the rate of change of wind speed is simply taken as the standard deviation in wind speed that is observed over the averaging interval, as proposed by Melbourne.11 Choosing this parameter will yield the average percentage of regions affected by dynamic stall during the 1 h interval. As mentioned earlier, since the type of airfoil also has a significant effect on the threshold radius, two different blades will be considered based on the airfoil type under the same conditions. The first blade consists of the S809 airfoil, for which the limiting reduced frequency is 0.026, whereas the other blade consists of a NACA 0012 airfoil, for which the limiting reduced frequency is 0.05. For these blades, the distribution of threshold radius based on the hourly averaged wind conditions for selected azimuth angles, with linear interpolation in between those angles, is shown in Figure 7. Moreover, negative pitching of an equal intensity is also considered to cause dynamic stall. Figure 7.
Comparison of the threshold radius distribution with azimuth angle based on hourly averaged wind conditions. The comparison is made between two theoretical wind turbines, experiencing the same wind conditions but with different airfoil sections making up the blade.

From Figure 7, it can be observed that, due to the yaw angle and the rate of change of yaw angle, the distribution of the threshold radius is asymmetrical about both the horizontal and the vertical axis. Moreover, dynamic stall is more prominent during the first half of the rotation cycle (0° < ψ < 180°) unlike the NREL case presented earlier, where the latter half of the rotation cycle is more affected (180° < ψ < 360°). This is due to the negative yaw angle used in this case. Furthermore, based on the above distribution, it can be observed that approximately 90% of the S809-blade will be under the influence of dynamic stall between azimuth angles of 60°–120°. Comparing this with the NACA 0012-blade, it can be seen that, due to the inherent resistance of the foil to dynamic stall, approximately 70% of the blade is affected during the same range of azimuth angles. Note that the distributions of threshold radius with azimuth angle for both types of blades are alike, since both blades are experiencing the same wind conditions. However, for all azimuths, the NACA 0012-blade shows a smaller affected region. Therefore, under the given conditions, the wind turbine with NACA 0012 airfoil is likely to have a longer operational life and/or larger intervals between maintenance runs, due to smaller regions affected by dynamic stall.

For the second case, the peak gust observed during the 1 h averaging interval is used to obtain the rate of change of wind speed. It is assumed that the entire wind turbine faces the peak gust at the same instant, generally termed as a ‘gust envelope’.27 This represents the worst-case flow to which the wind turbine can be exposed and needs to be analysed to ensure structural integrity. Note that the average gust duration is taken to be a constant (4 s), as explained earlier. The distribution of threshold radius as a function of azimuth angle for gust-envelope case for the two blades made up of different airfoils is shown in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Comparison of threshold radius distribution with azimuth angle based on the peak gust experienced during the 1 h averaging time. The comparison is made between two theoretical wind turbines, with different airfoil sections making the blade but experiencing the same wind conditions.

Let us, first of all, consider the situation where the turbine blade is composed of the S809 airfoil. As indicated in Figure 8, when a wind turbine is exposed to peak gusts, the entire turbine blade will experience dynamic stall between azimuth angles of 60°–150°. It should however be noted that the statement that 100% of S809-blade is affected by the dynamic stall is arguably not correct, since the flow field near the tip is subject to the disturbances from radial flows and tip-vortex generation. A simple comparison of the NACA 0012-blade under the same conditions shows that the 0012-blade is more resistant to dynamic stall occurrence due to the airfoil having a larger limiting reduced frequency. For this case, it can be observed from Figure 8 that under the peak gust and a moderate yaw angle, 80% of the blade is affected by dynamic stall. The information made available is extremely useful, since economical application of dynamic stall control devices requires the determination of the affected regions. Therefore, for the S809-blade placed at this site, the entire blade needs to be augmented with dynamic stall control whereas for the NACA 0012-airfoil, a smaller percentage of the blade-span needs the required control.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The threshold radius has been defined as the percentage of blade span beyond which the probability of dynamic stall occurrence falls to zero. The analytical model proposed in the article predicts the threshold radius, based on the ambient wind conditions. High quality wind data were used to determine the average wind conditions that serve as the model inputs. It was shown using the analytical model that the percentage of the blade affected by dynamic stall is largely dependent on the ambient wind conditions and the type of airfoil used for the turbine blades. Using the model, it was observed that the rate of change of wind speed (due by turbulence or gusts), yaw misalignment of the rotor, and the rate of change yaw angle (due to constantly changing wind direction) result in a considerable increase of the threshold radius. Furthermore, the choice of airfoil also has a large impact on the threshold radius, depending on the limiting reduced frequency for which dynamic stall was observed on the airfoil. It was shown that the NACA 0012 airfoil is more resistant to dynamic stall as compared to the S809 airfoil, due to the higher limiting reduced frequency. It should be noted that the distribution of threshold radius with azimuth angle for both the examples (NACA 0012 and S809 airfoil) considered in the article are very similar. This is primarily because the operating environment for both the airfoils considered is the same.

The model, therefore, serves as a useful toolbox for accurate predictions of regions of dynamic stall on the wind turbine blade, based on ambient wind conditions. This information is necessary for quick estimations of blade loads under unsteady conditions. However, for this purpose, the intensity of dynamic stall and its dependence on the reduced frequency for the particular airfoil needs to be considered. A further application of the model is that it provides the means to economically situate the control devices through accurate determination of the affected regions when dynamic stall control for wind turbine applications is required.

In the future, the effects of induced velocities, skewed wake and tower shadow will be included in the model for improved predictions. Furthermore, research will be carried out in order to determine the limiting reduced frequencies of different airfoils that are used in the wind turbine industry and the dependence of the limiting reduced frequencies on airfoil geometric parameters and Reynolds number. Such a study will aid in the design of airfoils that are inherently resistant to dynamic stall due to larger limiting reduced frequencies, ensuring a longer service life and better power characteristics of the turbine by considerable reduction of the unsteady aerodynamic loads on the turbine blades.
